perturbation.original_text: Marketing Affiliate shall pay to  Equidata, as compensation for its providing of Services under this agreement, such amounts as outlined and detailed in  Exhibit A attached hereto. Such amounts shall be billed on a bi-monthly basis by Equidata and are due and payable in  full by Marketing Affiliate 30 days from the invoice date. The prices set forth in Exhibit A do not include regulatory  fees, sales tax, excise tax or any other fees or taxes that may be charged by states or local taxing authorities nor does it  include additional fees or surcharges, including specific area Affiliate charges that may be accessed by the Credit  Reporting Agencies (CRA's). Said amounts charged to Equidata will be billed separately to Marketing Affiliate and are  due immediately upon receipt.
perturbation.changed_text: Marketing Affiliate shall pay to Equidata, as compensation for its providing of Services under this agreement, such amounts as outlined and detailed in Exhibit A attached hereto. Such amounts shall be billed on a bi-monthly basis by Equidata and are due and payable in full by Marketing Affiliate 60 days from the invoice date. The prices set forth in Exhibit A do not include regulatory fees, sales tax, excise tax or any other fees or taxes that may be charged by states or local taxing authorities nor does it include additional fees or surcharges, including specific area Affiliate charges that may be accessed by the Credit Reporting Agencies (CRA's). Said amounts charged to Equidata will be billed separately to Marketing Affiliate and are due immediately upon receipt.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment deadline from 30 days to 60 days in this section contradicts the late fee clause, creating confusion. The late fee is assessed based on the original 30-day payment term, but now the payment term is 60 days according to this section. This introduces ambiguity about when late fees apply, as the original clause states a penalty for payments after 30 days, but this modification allows 60 days. The original late fee clause is unaffected in section 1, so this creates a direct contradiction.

perturbation.original_text: The Marketing Affiliate agrees to pay a late charge of 1 l/2% per month on the unpaid, past-due amount  as well as a returned check fee of not less than $35.00 per returned item. In addition, the Marketing Affiliate agrees to  pay 25% attorney's fees plus court cost in the event that the Marketing Affiliate's account is referred to an attorney for  collection.
perturbation.changed_text: The Marketing Affiliate agrees to pay a late charge of 1 l/2% per month on the unpaid, past-due amount as well as a returned check fee of not less than $35.00 per returned item. In addition, the Marketing Affiliate agrees to pay 5% attorney's fees plus court cost in the event that the Marketing Affiliate's account is referred to an attorney for collection.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text introduces a contradiction by changing the attorney's fees percentage from 25% to 5%. This in-text contradiction creates uncertainty about the amount of attorney's fees the Marketing Affiliate is responsible for in case of collection.

perturbation.original_text: Marketing Affiliate shall give Equidata written demand of dispute within 10 days of the due date of the invoice. The  demand shall set forth a statement for the nature of the dispute and the amount involved. If Equidata and Marketing  Affiliate can not resolve the dispute on their own within 10 days after Equidata receive said dispute, the parties shall  jointly select an arbitrator.
perturbation.changed_text: Marketing Affiliate shall give Equidata written demand of dispute within 30 days of the due date of the invoice. The demand shall set forth a statement for the nature of the dispute and the amount involved. If Equidata and Marketing Affiliate can not resolve the dispute on their own within 5 days after Equidata receive said dispute, the parties shall jointly select an arbitrator.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text creates an in-text contradiction by changing the dispute demand deadline to 30 days and shortening the time for resolution before arbitration to 5 days. This modifies two different conditions of the dispute settlement process. This creates confusion about the time available for the resolution process.
